reviewText:
Game for mobile, crossed over to Steam to put things simply. Not the kind of game you'd play on PC. Could be great on a phone however. This is not the place for it, nor is it the place for any mobile game.

Pros
* Fun in First person, haven't seen that in a Tower Defense game before.
* Lost of upgrade options for turrets.
* Instead of In-app purchases it has a GIANT Free Coins! Banner across the top you can get free coins daily.

Cons
* Giant banner across the top.
* In-game only achievements, no Steam Achievements nor cards.
* Poor graphics, as it was not designed for PC.
* Music is repetitive.
* Unable to customize many keybindings, some things don't even have keybindings.
* Overpriced, I wouldn't pay $9.99 for it on mobile let alone on Steam.
* Not to mention I can find better Tower Defense games on kongregate. For Free.

reviewText:
Android game

Commando Jack is an android port of the same game now on steam.

There is barely any story at all. Basically, aliens have invaded earth and it's up to Commando Jack to stop them.

Gameplay is a mix of tower defence and first person shooting. Each level starts you off on one side of the map with a turret, trying to defend against the alien invasion. You have limited time at the start to build towers and set traps for defences before the waves begin. Besides building defences you can also switch to your main turret and shoot the aliens via first-person. Enemy waves get more numerous and stronger as the level progresses. The aliens will move towards you main turret and try to destroy it, which results in a gameover should it happen. After each level, you will earn up to 3 stars depending on whether the enemy was able to attack your main turret or not. You also earn credits, which are used to buy/upgrade turrets at the store before each level. There are variety of aliens including snipers, tanks standards and elemental which all have certain strengths and weaknesses. A variety of turrets are also available including machine gun, rockets, mines, lasers and sand bags. One of the problems I found was that when you upgrade turrets' you don't know how the turret was improved as you don't get to see any statistics.

Graphics aren't great. The android history, shows off on the low detailed models for guns, environment, turrets (everything really).

Sound effects are quite poor. Weapons sounds are basic. Background music is forgettable. There is not voice acting in the game.

Unless this game is highly discounted, I recommend that you stay clear of this game. It's not that this game is terrible, its just that there are dozens of games which do a better job at representing the 'tower defence genre' and cheaper too.

reviewText:
The tower defense game Commando Jack originally made its way to iPhones way back in 2012, but just recently its developer Colossal Games released this on Steam. So the question on everyone‚Äôs mind right now is: is this a ‚Äòquick‚Äô cash-in or this is a port that all PC gamers can be content with ?

And while I‚Äôm definitely going to explain more about the game in just a minute I can already answer the question I just brought up: it‚Äôs absolutely a game made to make some extra money. No, this isn‚Äôt a bad game per se, it‚Äôs just not optimized for us PC gamers: the game starts instantly with the first mission, no menus or anything, video options aren‚Äôt there and it forces a low resolution game into fullscreen, making the whole thing look blurry as a result (Alt+Enter does work, mind you). Which to me, looks like a really bad start, wouldn‚Äôt you agree ?
Thankfully Commando Jack is one of the better tower defense titles out there, and this one gives you the opportunity to shoot some aliens yourself, in first person view. It doesn‚Äôt use in-app purchases like the iOS version does, but it does have things like ‚ÄòFree coins‚Äô banners at the top of the screen when you‚Äôre not killing enemies. It‚Äôs not even subtle. Unfortunately, these coins have to be used to buy and upgrade turrets, buy power-ups and also to upgrade your stationary gun, so there‚Äôs no way to just not click on it. You‚Äôll get coins by finishing missions, clicking on a Free Coins button every day or by hacking into aliens‚Äô accounts (which can also be done once a day). I never seemed to run out of cash during my game sessions; the game hands out large amounts of coins at the same time. So why does it have to be so in-your-face then ? I honestly have no idea.
There are 45 campaign missions to finish, and then there‚Äôs also Endless mode, Mixed mode (normal enemies mixed with fire and ice enemies) and Elemental mode, which throws only ice and fire enemies at you. There are special towers for both these ice and fire enemies, and special ammo can be bought for your stationary gun. Levels aren‚Äôt just squares, they have all kind of different shapes and because of that It‚Äôs not always easy to create a long, difficult maze for enemies to walk through.
If an enemy gets through you can always go to your stationary gun with the press of a button and kill them yourself. However, your gun can also overheat so it‚Äôs necessary to use it with caution. Snipers can also spawn on the battlefield, out of view, and they can only be killed in first person view. It‚Äôs fun, but the first few times you might not notice them quickly enough and you‚Äôll probably see your base‚Äôs health drop within seconds. After that you‚Äôll most likely pay more attention to your surroundings.
Other than all of things I just mentioned this is your basic tower defense game. That‚Äôs not meant as a negative argument, but it‚Äôs the same thing as, let‚Äôs say, point-and-click adventures. They‚Äôre usually the same as far as gameplay is concerned, but sometimes they have a little bit more variety. The same goes for Commando Jack.

So, apart from the cluttered user interface and the non-existent video options, what‚Äôs there to say about this game technically ? Well, the models use some sharp textures, which is good, but the models on the other hand are blocky. Some of it seems intentional, some of it doesn‚Äôt. The game does a nice job at showing you landmarks and other country related objects in each of the different locations. London has a Big Ben tower and Japan has cherry trees, for example.
The music seems to change whenever you change cities, so if you‚Äôre fighting in Japan you‚Äôll hear music with Japanese influences. The sound effects overall are also very good and clear.
Game length also seems to be good; this could take you several hours to tens of hours if you want to 100% the entire game. I personally think it‚Äôs best played in smaller sessions.

Commando Jack doesn‚Äôt completely reinvent the genre but the gameplay is fun enough as long as you can ignore the things that clearly show we‚Äôre dealing with an iOS port here. From a technical viewpoint I would not recommend it, but as a game I think I would. But just barely. And that‚Äôs mainly the reason why this gets a below average rating in my book.

[Rating: 63/100]

reviewText: It is difficult to describe Commando Jack. I suppose the closest game I can equate it with would be Plants Verses Zombies, only with a Military fighting an Alien Invasion twist, multiple boards to play on, and an array of purchasable weaponry, designed to combat various threats. You earn coins by completing levels, which you are graded on similar to the 3 star level grading system on many Facebook games. You can spend those coins upgrading your weapons, to combat various alien threats. Each board has a different layout, and the layout changes and becomes more complicated depending on the difficulty setting you are playing at. The game allows for Easy play, which is fairly straight-forward and is recommended for the casual player, Medium, Hard, and Extreme, for only the most serious of gamers. You are tasked with stopping Alien threats, which come in the form of a portal, after which you must defeat waves of aliens, by placing weapons in strategic places to destroy the aliens as they advance from the portal. This game really took me by surprise and was a lot of fun to play. It is a very inexpensive game, fun, and easy to learn, so I would give it a thumbs up if it sounds like the sort of game you would enjoy. I don't think you will be disappointed.

reviewText:
Commando Jack really baffles me. It only takes some cursory browsing to see all the bizarre raving from (what I can only imagine to be) sorely out of context quotes and even nominations for awards. Yet after only a very brief period of play in which I made it through the tutorial and first couple levels, it was overwhelmingly clear that this game was just another bland mobile port.

At first glance Commando Jack would strike you as a typical mobile shovelware quality tower defense; however, upon digging into the game a little deeper you will discover that it is in fact.. exactly what it appears to be. The store page has GameTrailers hailing it as ‚Äú...unlike anything we‚Äôve ever played before.‚Äù It pulls into question the actual amount of time anyone at GT has ever really been in the gaming community. ‚ÄúTower defense with a first-person twist!‚Äù proclaims another hideously flagrant screenshot. On and on these quotes go, yet the game is bad. Even if I had gotten this on my android phone or tablet I would have been revolted by the graphics, infuriated by the responsiveness of controlling the turret and utterly bored at the experience of playing yet another tower defense game.

I‚Äôm so very glad I spent nothing on this game, that is all it‚Äôs worth. Even then I didn‚Äôt get my moneys worth.

reviewText:
Played the game for a while and have so far really enjoyed the experience.  It is a tower defense game with a few twists which set it apart from many of the other games in the genre.  I wouldn't say it was the best of the bunch but, at the price it sells for, is definitely good value.

For those people who complain because it was a mobile game and believe that it should stay that way, I highly disagree.  I have two young children and am happy for them to use the computer to play these kind of games as it only costs a small amount of money to replace a mouse it they break it.  I am certainly not going to give them several hundred pounds worth of moile technology to play it on so, in my opinion, there is absolutely nothing wrong with these kind of games being released on Steam also.

reviewText: Game sucks. Clearly a mobile game. No graphic or control settings in game at all. Terrible resolution can't change. The game home page and original menus is confusing and not easily accessed. The controls/different menus in game are not helpful and not explained. Switching back and forth between turret and placing weapons is annoying and not quick. Buttons that are used on computer and should do certain things don't work or do anything and you have to use mouse. A lot of turrets you don't know what they do or what they are useful for an aren't explained well. Levels suck and can only place towers in certain spots, and in some levels they can just get around them for no apparent reason. Can't maze or make your own setup because some levels are just made that way because it makes no sense. Clearly a free-to place game with huge banner for getting coins which you use in game, which you can like their facebook page to get more off, shoddy marketing.\n\nYou can level up new towers but also upgrade them, 2 different systems that seem to do the same thing but is unclear. Game gives you no idea what effect you buying upgrades does. Towers seem undewhelming. You have to look at certain guys come and plan your towers accordingly. No clue which towers are needed and which are useful, and sucky game menues and UI doesn't help. Half of the buttons you can click on and powers you use aren't explained. No story. Clearly 0 effort put into bringing this game to PC/steam. Hell it's even hard to figure out how to exit the game, probably on purpose because everyone who starts it up would instantly want to. Not worth any money, I got it for free and I'm still disappointed and feel ripped off. 3/10.

reviewText: It's not a bad game per say, just pretty generic. It is actually put together decently for a mobile port and can be somewhat entertaining. The main problem with it is that I noticed that you do everything with the mouse and there are no real meaningful keyboard shortcuts just some basic ones. You should have more configuration options but you don't. That and the fact that it is a poor mans version of OTTTD or Sanctum 2, I won't put any more time in it than the initial 30 minutes sinced those two games are far superior than this.\n\nMany much better TD games exist including the two I mentioned where your time will be much more well spent than here. The regular price for this of $10 is laughable, $5 or less is more like it. I got it for free from indiegala.com but I will have much more fun playing other TD games I have.

reviewText: I got this game as a free giveaway so I have no real complaints about the product itself as it's all functional.  There are dozens and dozens of levels with just enough variety to have to try different things.  As for why this game isn't a top seller is that it lacks some polish in terms of interface (sometimes not being able to place turrets correctly) a lack of tooltips at times and way too many notifications going on throughout that mean almost nothing to the gameplay.  Overall it's not a horrible experience for those who have never played games like Sanctum or Orcs must Die which would be the few steps up from this.

reviewText: Ok this is something really interesting. TD games always had this problem regarding player actions: you build towers and just watch. By solving the problem of player implication this game made TD quite addictive and more action packed. Personaly blowing up the enemy suicidal waves is much more engaging than just watching my towers bombard tiny running specs.

reviewText:
Fun but is a bad mobile port! The game is fun for a short period of time but as it was made for the mobile, the fun does not last. The game has not had a good port, the controls have not been re-bound properly (W, A, S, D are used to move the camera for the character) and there are no graphical options (not even a full screen or windowed option).
There is not much else to say about this game, it does not have many features to comment on.
Pros:
Fun for a short period of time.
Good time filler, easily get distracted on this game. Cons:
Bad mobile port.
Controls not bound properly.
Each level is to short and easy.

reviewText:
I have a soft spot for tower defense games that stretches all the way back to the glory days of Onslaught 2. Commando Jack is a welcome edition to the genre, putting you (Jack) in the position of ridding some base of some aliens somewhere. You control a large turret from first person perspective, and can swap camera views in order to build your turrets. The game sports a small tutorial at the beginning, but learning becomes very organic (and a lot easier if you're familiar with tower defense games).

Each variation of alien comes with it's own soft spot (a weakness for you to hit with the turret) and there are SEVERAL different variations of small turrets to soften them up before they reach you. Turrets are purchased with in-game currency that is both readily available, and easy to earn. A single successful round will net you about 50,000, with the new turrets typically costing around half of that.

A feature strongly promoted by the game is building a maze of turrets for the aliens to go through. It's a bit remniscient of Pipe Dream" in that you have a starting point
date: and want to funnel the aliens through it in a complex path that allows for maximum damage output.\n\nHighly recommend for any fans of tower defense games
recommended: as this is a really well thought out title in the genre."
voteText: true

reviewText: This is a fun tower defense mixed with some FPS elements. However, this version is clearly a terrible PC port from an originally mobile game. They literally left all the extra mobile app crap in like daily rewards, liking them on facebook and twitter, free coins"
date: etc. The game itself is fun but now I suppose I'll uninstall it and look for it on my tablet because it's terrible on the PC in this state."

reviewText:
Commando Jack is a 'mobile' gamed through and through. From the low resolution to the awkward controls. Although done before (Sanctum comes to mind), this game introduces a mechanic where you are capable of shooting the enemies yourself. I find such a mechanic annoying because if I wanted to play sub-par FPS games, I would play said games.

The game has no spirit. The sound, the graphics, the story and the turrets are all cookie-cutter and the developer receives an F- for effort on all fronts. The only thing it does well is not having the game crash.

It's also terribly boring and you can feel a part of your brain wither away as you play it.
The difference between PC gaming and mobile gaming is about 50 IQ points, that much is obvious.

reviewText:
Product received for free

very cheap-feeling tower-defense game where the main gimmick is being able to go into first-person mode and shoot waves manually. it's actually kind of a pain to do so, especially since there's no real visual feedback when your shots hit. indeed, the visuals in general are uninspiring, and they haven't even bothered to remove the parts of the game like GET FREE COINS buttons which clearly show it's just a rushed port of a mobile game.

i don't even remember how this ended up in my games list so i'm gonna just assume it was part of a giveaway. it still isn't worth it for free.
